elements.label: No Easy Roads Ahead
elements.description: A long march awaits.

elements.label: Ruined Country
elements.description: These war-torn stretches offer little in the way of relief or comfort. We should pass through here as quickly as we can. [Few opportunities of use, and strange enemies are abroad in this place.]

elements.label: Ruined Country
elements.description: These war-torn stretches offer little in the way of relief or comfort. We should pass through here as quickly as we can. [Few opportunities of use, and strange enemies are abroad in this place.]

elements.label: Bialystok
elements.description: The speartip of the German invasion fell here. Defence is increasingly tenuous; the Wehrmacht pushes forward relentlessly; the Polish despise both us and them. Let's make a smooth exit while that is still a possibility.

elements.label: Bialystok
elements.description: Over the course of two years, the people of Bialystok have suffered German occupation, then Soviet seizure, then the needlings of the NKVD, and now again the Germans have returned to take what was rightfully given to the Union. The pitiless push and pull of politics. Power.

elements.label: Vilna
elements.description: We have not held Vilna for more than two years, and now the Germans come to seize our partition of Lithuania. There will be consequences to face if we let them do it.

elements.label: Vilna
elements.description: The city of the Iron Wolf; the city of the Gate of Dawn. The Lithuanians have not made it easy to hold onto Vilna, but then I suppose no people have ever been happy to be annexed.

elements.label: Minsk
elements.description: We stole the bones of Lithuanian-Polish industry and shipped them here to do their work: foundries, factories, diggers and rail-layers. They have done such admirable work for us - let us not allow them to be shamed by having to work in the employ of the Germans.

elements.label: Minsk
elements.description: Whole buildings lie crumbled, spilling their skeletons of wood and brick onto the worn cobbled streets, and no-one shall pick up the pieces yet. Wehrmacht shelling has been most unkind to the city of Minsk - the latest in a line of many, many unkindnesses.

elements.label: Vitebsk
elements.description: Vitebsk - we will have to give up this playing-piece in time. But even if we cannot hold the city against the Wehrmacht indefinitely, there are other victories we can seek among the stones and the streets.

elements.label: Vitebsk
elements.description: Saint Olga founded this City, and in those older days the Varangians and the Greeks came here for trade. This century has seen it pass through the hands of four different republics. Now half the people who once lived here have fled east, as they should.

elements.label: Orsha
elements.description: On the fork of the Dneiper and the Arshytsa, there is Orsha. The two waterways have made it important enough to fight over; on that, both we and the Germans agree.

elements.label: Orsha
elements.description: Stendhal came here when the Corsican seized control the place (and after the burning of the town), and wrote little of it. It is easy to see why - there is little to write of Orsha. In fact, in the near future, I anticipate there will be little of Orsha at all.

elements.label: Smolensk
elements.description: Another fine jewel of Soviet industry: food, textiles, manufacturing, even the processing of actual jewels. If we cannot abscond with this jewel, then neither will the Germans. We must go to work with decisive swiftness and a generous number of demolition charges.

elements.label: Smolensk
elements.description: The Corsican came here with his Grande Arm√©e more than a century ago. Before them were the Teutons, the Lithuanians, and the Mongols. Now the city of Smolensk watches with her windowed eyes and implacable statues as yet another band of small conquerors spills blood upon her stones.

elements.label: Vyazma
elements.description: Long has Vyazma been a brute deterrent against invaders striving towards Moscow. An encirclement by the Wehrmacht has broken apart the defences here, and we'll have to make do with the pieces.

elements.label: Vyazma
elements.description: Smoke and gunfire beyond the Hodegetria church. Bombers cast their periodic shadows over the town, passing overhead like the scorn of an indecisive god.

elements.label: Rzhev
elements.description: Another mean encirclement by the enemy has already resulted in the decimation and dissolution of a large part of our force here. Now those who remain thrash against the tightening jaws of the German war machine, and against the coming of the pitiless snows.

elements.label: Rzhev
elements.description: Winter strangles Rzhev, starves it. But the rats and the flies grow fat here.

elements.label: Bryansk
elements.description: Bryansk will be in the hands of the Germans soon, but they won't hold it for long if we have anything to say about it. After Stalingrad, we'll return here for what belongs to us.

elements.label: Bryansk
elements.description: The Svenskaya Fair was here once, but the Empire put an end to that long ago. Bryansk was put towards making cannons and gunpowder, then later to rifles and armoured transports for the Bolsheviks. History builds up in the bones of this place, no matter who comes to crack their weapons against the gates and erase it.

elements.label: Kyiv
elements.description: The long soul of the Rus, now under inexorable threat. The wolves close in on all sides. Stem the bleeding long enough so that we may draw our industry east.

elements.label: Kyiv
elements.description: The OPRP has always paid close attention to happenings in Kyiv. The city has a penchant for attracting the uncanny, and less than twenty years ago, a Ligeian laired here. The Ligeian is elsewhere now (I hope), but now the Germans have arrived to take her place. I am not sure whether or not that is an improvement in our fortunes.

elements.label: Kursk
elements.description: The fields outside the city crawl with German tanks and mean, armoured things. This battlefield is meant only for mean, armoured things, I think. But we have our orders. No shirking.

elements.label: Kursk
elements.description: Igor the Brave said of the Kurskers: 'The bows they have are strung tight, the quivers, unclosed, the sabers, sharpened; themselves, like gray wolves, they lope in the field, seeking for themselves honor, and for their prince, glory.' Of course, Prince Igor ultimately failed to drive the Polovstians from the banks of the Don - but at least his account was very stirring. I'll carry it with me when I'm facing down a German tank.

elements.label: Livny
elements.description: Another small buffer between east and west. This small town is characteristically Russian: it bears its pain quietly, no matter how many years of tribulation pass.

elements.label: Livny
elements.description: A long pedigree of suffering here in Livny: the Tatars came with fire, the Cossacks with sabres, the Crimeans with rifles. So many times has this place been rebuilt from ashes. What is one more?

elements.label: Voronezh
elements.description: This is the centre point of the Black Earth region, where the rich soil holds now the bones of forced industrialization like sudden, new muscles; where railway-arteries stretch to Moscow upon land that was once darkest forest.

elements.label: Voronezh
elements.description: Beyond the factory fences, Katyushas have been wheeled out and pointed west, anticipating the approach of any German contingent. We sleep, but the artillery does not. And sometimes, when we sleep, we dream of the safety of mist.

elements.label: Kharkiv
elements.description: Kharkiv is the product of Stalin's hardline for industrial strength in the Soviet Union. Even when people starved in the streets during the Holodomor, Kharkiv's factories churned with dutiful fire and smoke. The arrival of the Wehrmacht may upset the routine of work. It may.

elements.label: Kharkiv
elements.description: The first of the Five-Year Plans had the old city uprooted - churches and monuments all - to make room for Stalin's precious industry. The NKVD came later to uproot the intellectuals, the writers, the artists of the Ukraine. When I worked for the OPRP, I came here to uproot an errant labhite, once. I still bear the scars.

elements.label: Uman
elements.description: The Luftwaffe have harried and bombed the troops passing through Uman into despair and exhaustion. Mechanised infantry have been reduced to mere footsoldiers carrying rifles. We had best withdraw from the city with those servicemen who can still fight.

elements.label: Uman
elements.description: The defence of the city is an exercise in futility. Budyonny plays a bad hand against a ruthless opponent - I imagine Stalin will be upset with him once we are forced to pull back from Uman. He might even be executed. As we move on the outskirts and exchange rifle-fire with the Germans, that scrap of gallows humour warms me just enough.

elements.label: Odessa
elements.description: The city's seat upon the Black Sea has made it desirable to the Germans as an object of conquest, and desirable to us as a position we must hold onto for as long as possible. It won't last forever - but we do not need forever.

elements.label: Odessa
elements.description: Here once was all Europe, come by sea to do trade on the ports the Empress built. Here once was revolutionary blood spilled on the steps, the first embers of the Bolshevik conflagration. Here once there was something like peace. Now it is gone, and we are here instead.

elements.label: Perekop
elements.description: After the Revolution, the Bolsheviks built farming towns here, and trade ensued. The Germans come to take the place, now; to sever the bridge between Crimea and Ukraine. They will likely have it, but that does not mean we need to leave the place in a condition fit for having.

elements.label: Perekop
elements.description: There was a fort on the isthmus here, once - the redoubtable gate to Crimea - and it weathered many, many sieges. But the centuries have brought low the walls and dried up the moats, and so now we are the only measure of defence against the invaders.

elements.label: Izium
elements.description: The Germans destroyed a large salient of our troops on the outskirts of the city - a disastrous miscalculation by the luminaries of the Red Army. Days are numbered in Izium. Blood flows plentifully.

elements.label: Izium
elements.description: In the 17th century, the Cossacks set roots here. They could not have possibly anticipated the great change and industry the next centuries would bring to their fortress-town. But war - the war which has come now to Izium - this the Cossacks knew would always be Russia's way.

elements.label: Stalingrad
elements.description: Here we must finally turn the tide of the German invasion; here the Corrivality burns at its hottest; here I might finally find my destiny.

elements.label: Stalingrad
elements.description: Bombardment and gunfire have scarred each inch of the Premier's city. We walk here amidst the ruins, hide in the shadows when the bombers pass, and kill the enemy wherever they might be found. And above - above are the Edge Hours, watching as men die in the hundreds just to advance the perimeter a street forward. I could not ask for a better stage.

elements.label: A Vision of the Lake
elements.description: 'Ebrehel is kept beneath the water's skin at the lake that cannot be visited twice, beyond the charting of men.' In dreams, I see that lake.

elements.label: The Unseen Lake
elements.description: The Twins often flout the laws of the House, and keep certain secrets from the other Hours. This place is one such secret. No-one who comes upon the lake may find it again, and the Twins are liable to place it somewhere else in the world when the next cycle of the moon turns.

elements.label: Lonely Places Between
elements.description: Do Edge-Long flee? The Iron-Eater seems to have. He's rode from the field of battle back into the cold night. I could pursue him. He'll be plenty dangerous, still - but now I know what makes him afraid.

elements.label: Lonely Places Between
elements.description: 'On this road there are no godspoke men. They are gone and I am left and they have taken with them the world.' - Cormac McCarthy, The Road
